content.title: Government and the Economy ‚Äî Personal Impact
content.subtitle: Understand why markets sometimes fail and how government intervention shapes your financial life in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
Why does the government pay for roads and public schools but not your groceries?

The answer reveals a fundamental economic logic ‚Äî and directly affects how your tax dollars are spent in {{STATE_NAME}}.

objectives.description: Why free markets sometimes fail to allocate resources efficiently, creating a role for government intervention
The characteristics of public goods, private goods, and common resources ‚Äî and how governments provide each
How positive and negative externalities cause markets to over- or under-produce, and what policies correct them
The personal financial impact of key government programs, taxes, and regulations in {{STATE_NAME}}

terms.definition: A good that is non-excludable (no one can be prevented from using it) and non-rival (one person's use doesn't reduce availability for others), which the private market typically underprovides
terms.example: National defense ‚Äî your neighbors' protection from attack doesn't reduce your own protection, and no private company can profit from providing it to paying customers only

terms.definition: A cost or benefit that falls on a third party not involved in the transaction ‚Äî markets ignore these spillovers, causing over- or under-production of certain goods
terms.example: A neighbor's loud music (negative externality on you) or a homeowner's beautiful garden that increases surrounding property values (positive externality for neighbors)

terms.definition: A situation where the free market fails to allocate resources efficiently, resulting in outcomes that are worse for society than a well-designed government intervention could achieve
terms.example: Healthcare markets where information gaps, insurance complexity, and emergency needs prevent normal market pricing from working efficiently for everyone

terms.definition: When individuals benefit from a public good without paying for it ‚Äî since exclusion is impossible ‚Äî causing private markets to underprovide goods society needs
terms.example: Broadcast television ‚Äî you can watch without paying, so stations can't charge viewers directly and must rely on advertising revenue instead

leftColumn.title: Public Goods
items: Non-excludable ‚Äî Cannot prevent anyone from using it
Non-rival ‚Äî One person's use doesn't reduce others' access
Free rider problem ‚Äî No profit motive for private providers
Government must fund through taxes
Examples: National defense, public roads, street lighting, public parks

rightColumn.title: Private Goods
items: Excludable ‚Äî Can prevent non-payers from accessing it
Rival ‚Äî One person's use reduces availability for others
Private market can provide profitably through prices
Government typically does not need to provide
Examples: Food, clothing, cars, haircuts, streaming subscriptions

content.headerTitle: Externalities ‚Äî Markets Miss the Full Picture

leftPanel.title: Costs and Benefits Beyond the Transaction
paragraphs: When a buyer and seller make a deal, third parties may be helped or harmed without compensation. These spillovers cause markets to produce too much or too little of certain goods.
bulletPoints: Negative Externality ‚Äî Factory pollutes a river, harming community health; market produces too much pollution
Positive Externality ‚Äî Vaccination reduces disease risk for everyone; market produces too few vaccines without intervention
Policy for Negative Externality ‚Äî Tax the activity (carbon tax) or regulate it (EPA pollution limits)
Policy for Positive Externality ‚Äî Subsidize it (free vaccines) or require it (mandatory school attendance laws in {{STATE_NAME}})

stats.label: Annual cost of air pollution health effects in the US ‚Äî a negative externality borne by non-participants
Vaccination rate needed for herd immunity ‚Äî why government subsidizes vaccines
Primary tools governments use to correct externalities

layoutData.title: Market Failures Require Policy Solutions
paragraphs: Markets are powerful tools for allocating resources ‚Äî but they don't always work perfectly. When markets fail, government intervention can improve outcomes for society.
bulletPoints: Public Goods: Roads, defense, and public parks won't be provided privately ‚Äî the free rider problem makes private provision economically impossible
Externalities: Pollution and healthcare create spillovers not captured in prices ‚Äî taxes, subsidies, and regulations align private incentives with social benefits
Information Asymmetry: When sellers know more than buyers (used cars, healthcare), markets fail ‚Äî disclosure regulations improve outcomes for consumers
Market Power: Monopolies charge too much and produce too little ‚Äî antitrust enforcement and utility regulation protect consumers in {{STATE_NAME}}

keyPoint.text: üí° The economic question isn't whether government should ever intervene ‚Äî it's identifying when intervention improves outcomes and when it creates new problems. Evidence and analysis matter more than ideology.

content.headerTitle: Government Programs That Affect Your Finances

leftPanel.title: Programs Touching Your Life in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Government programs directly shape your financial situation through services you receive, taxes you pay, and protections you rely on every day.
bulletPoints: Public Education ‚Äî K-12 and state university funding dramatically reduces your cost of education
Social Security & Medicare ‚Äî Programs you pay into now that provide retirement and healthcare security later
Unemployment Insurance ‚Äî Income replacement if you lose your job in {{STATE_NAME}}; up to 26 weeks of partial income
FDIC Deposit Insurance ‚Äî Protects your bank savings up to $250,000 if your bank fails
Consumer Protections ‚Äî CFPB regulations prevent predatory lending and financial fraud targeting you

stats.label: Average annual government spending per K-12 student in the US
Payroll tax from each paycheck toward Social Security and Medicare
FDIC deposit insurance limit per depositor protecting your savings

leftPanel.title: What You Pay and Why It Matters
paragraphs: Taxes fund public goods and programs. Understanding how different taxes work helps you plan your finances and evaluate policy debates in {{STATE_NAME}}.
bulletPoints: Federal Income Tax ‚Äî Progressive rate structure from 10% to 37%; higher earners pay higher percentage
{{STATE_NAME}} State Income Tax ‚Äî Rate varies by state; some states have zero income tax
FICA Payroll Tax ‚Äî 7.65% from every paycheck for Social Security (6.2%) and Medicare (1.45%)
Sales Tax ‚Äî Applied to purchases in {{STATE_NAME}}; regressive ‚Äî takes larger share of income from lower earners
Property Tax ‚Äî Based on property value; primary funding source for local public schools in {{STATE_NAME}}

stats.label: Federal income tax ‚Äî higher earners pay higher rates
Sales tax ‚Äî takes larger share from lower-income households
Typical total effective tax rate for middle-income earners

layoutData.title: How Regulations Protect Your Financial Life
paragraphs: Government regulations set rules businesses must follow. While sometimes adding costs, regulations also protect consumers, workers, and the environment from harms that markets alone wouldn't prevent.
bulletPoints: FDIC Insurance: Protects your bank deposits up to $250,000 ‚Äî you don't lose savings if your bank fails
Truth in Lending Act: Lenders must disclose APR and total loan costs ‚Äî prevents hidden fee surprises when you borrow money
FDA Oversight: Medications must be proven safe and effective before reaching you ‚Äî protects from harmful or ineffective treatments
Labor Laws: Minimum wage, overtime rules, and OSHA workplace safety standards protect workers throughout {{STATE_NAME}}

keyPoint.text: üí° Before FDIC insurance (created 1933), bank failures wiped out depositors' entire savings. Regulation eliminated that risk ‚Äî one of the most impactful financial protections ever created for ordinary Americans.

leftColumn.title: Arguments FOR Intervention
items: Corrects market failures that hurt consumers and communities
Provides public goods markets won't supply
Protects vulnerable populations from exploitation
Reduces negative externalities (pollution, fraud)
Creates stability ‚Äî FDIC, unemployment insurance reduce economic panic

rightColumn.title: Arguments AGAINST Intervention
items: Regulations add compliance costs that raise prices
Government programs can be inefficient and wasteful
Taxes reduce incentives to work, invest, and innovate
Political decisions may not match economic needs
Unintended consequences can make problems worse

scenario.name: Jordan ‚Äî Health Insurance Subsidies
paragraphs: Jordan, age 23, recently aged off their parents' insurance and needed their own coverage. Earning $32,000/year part-time without employer benefits, Jordan visits healthcare.gov and discovers ACA marketplace subsidies.

Because Jordan's income falls in the subsidy-eligible range, the government covers most of the premium. Jordan pays $87/month instead of $450/month ‚Äî a $4,356 annual government subsidy addressing healthcare market failure.

scenario.name: The Martinez Family ‚Äî FDIC Saves Their Savings
paragraphs: During the 2008 financial crisis, several banks failed. The Martinez family had $180,000 in savings at one of the failed banks. Without FDIC insurance, they would have lost everything.
FDIC deposit insurance ‚Äî a government regulation ‚Äî protected every dollar of their savings, demonstrating how market regulation directly protects personal finances from banking system failures.

content.question:
Think about a government program or regulation that directly affects your life in {{STATE_NAME}} ‚Äî public schools, road maintenance, food safety standards, or labor laws.

Would the private market provide this on its own without government? Why or why not? Do you think the benefit outweighs the cost? How would your life differ without it?

When you hear debates about government spending and taxes in {{STATE_NAME}}, how do you evaluate whether a particular program is worth its cost?

What evidence would you need to support or oppose a new government program? How do the economic concepts of market failure and externalities help you think more clearly about when government involvement actually makes sense?

questions.question: What two characteristics define a public good? Why won't private markets provide public goods efficiently on their own?
Give one example of a positive externality and one of a negative externality. What government policy could address each one?
How does FDIC insurance protect your personal finances? What market failure does it address?
Why are sales taxes considered regressive while income taxes are progressive? How does each affect lower-income households in {{STATE_NAME}} differently?

takeaways.title: Markets Are Powerful but Imperfect
takeaways.description: Free markets excel at allocating most goods ‚Äî but fail with public goods, externalities, information gaps, and market power

takeaways.title: Public Goods Require Government
takeaways.description: Defense, roads, and public safety can't be profitably provided by private markets ‚Äî the free rider problem prevents efficient private provision

takeaways.title: Externalities Distort Markets
takeaways.description: Pollution creates negative spillovers; education and vaccines create positive ones ‚Äî taxes, subsidies, and regulations correct these distortions

takeaways.title: Government Programs Protect Your Finances
takeaways.description: FDIC insurance, Social Security, unemployment coverage, and consumer protections in {{STATE_NAME}} directly safeguard your financial security

main.title: Government Impact Analyzer
main.description: Explore how government programs and market failures interact in your life and in {{STATE_NAME}}'s economy. Use economic reasoning to evaluate real programs and form evidence-based opinions about government's role.

steps: Identify Market Failures ‚Äî List three markets in {{STATE_NAME}} showing public good, externality, or information asymmetry problems
Analyze Government Response ‚Äî For each market failure, identify the specific policy or program that addresses it
Calculate Personal Impact ‚Äî Estimate how government programs (education funding, deposit insurance, subsidies) benefit you financially per year
Evaluate Trade-offs ‚Äî For one program, identify both the benefits it provides and the costs (taxes paid, efficiency losses, reduced market incentives)
Form a Policy Position ‚Äî Based on your analysis, argue whether one government program in {{STATE_NAME}} should be expanded, reduced, or maintained at current levels
